data.title: The Crying Woman (1979)
data.meta_description: Jacques returns after a long absence to his wife Dominique and their daughter Lola in their isolated house, located on a hillside in Provence. Dominique is crouching and crying. She had asked Jacques to go because she could not stand him seeing her crying. Jacques powerlessly witnesses the excesses of Dominique's emotions. She understands that he loves another woman, and ousts him again...
data.text:
A few years after the release in 1975 of 'Un sac de billes', a film that follows two French Jewish boys during the Second Wold War, the 33 year old Jacques Doillon has an idea for another film. He has recently moved from Paris to Manosque, in the Alpes-de-Haute-Provence, about 90 km above Marseille.

To help the French film makers, André Malraux, minister of Cultural Aiffairs, had in 1959 developed a system of an 'advance on the revenue'. A commission, members of the CNC (Centre national du cinéma et de l'image animée) decided on this advance. From 1960 on many now famous directors could benefit from it:

Alain Resnais (L'Année dernière à Marienbad), Cléo de 5 à 7 (Agnès Varda),…
